Hi all,

I'm using a few neat-implementations (namely implementations by Ma=
tt Buckland, NEAT 2.5, modular NEAT and a HyperNEAT).
After a deep look ins=
ide them all i noticed some cost intensive using of activations, mostly to =
propagate signals from input- to output-layers.
In that manner the networks=
 are often activated up to 9 times or whichever the maximum of there layers=
 is.
In calculation intensive domains this will take a lot of time.
So I ca=
me up with the idea of unifying all the networks to just nodes (with values=
 and activation function) and links with weights.
Then creating an activati=
on order array with output nodes first.
Following by neurons inputing in al=
l the so far neurons in the list ignoring those already in the list until a=
ll neurons are traversed.
The network then gets activated by the inverse or=
der of the list, after setting the input neurons.

So here are my questions=
 on this where I'd like some comments on:
- are recurrences kept? (my simpl=
e understanding of them is that they model some sort of simple memory of th=
e networks last activation, so multiple network activations would destroy t=
hat concept anyway)
- does my simplification keep the normal behavior of th=
e network, esp. if it's only strict forward?

I use the whole simplificatio=
n of the activation for some evaluation speed ups, by creating a separate c=
pp file for the current population, compiling that one into a shared librar=
y with a little help of cmake. This library, created at runtime, is then us=
ed for fitness evaluation.
My first experiments with that show some major s=
peed increase for complex domains (in my case it's a khepera robot navigati=
ng in a maze with objective to explore most areas of the maze without crash=
ing into walls).
As you can see, there are lots of network activations need=
ed so the time to generate and compile the library has almost no weight in =
contrast to the speed gain of the network activation.

I'd appreciate any c=
omments on this and experience some of you could share.

Robin
